snippet: “Le Tricorne,” a 95-year-old stage curtain painted by Pablo Picasso, was removed from Manhattan’s Four Seasons restaurant early Sunday morning, but not before its frailty produced a few tense moments.
abstract: Le Tricorne, a 19 by 20 foot stage curtain painted by Pablo Picasso is very carefully removed from Four Seasons restaurant on Park Avenue, its home since 1959; curtain was caught in a dispute between the New York Landmarks Conservancy, which owns the piece, and Aby J Rosen, the owner of the landmark Seagram Building where it resided, who wanted it taken away; curtain's new home will be New-York Historical Society.
lead_paragraph: “Le Tricorne,” a 95-year-old stage curtain painted by Pablo Picasso, was removed from Manhattan’s Four Seasons restaurant early Sunday morning, but not before its frailty produced a few tense moments.

headline.main: After 55 Years in Vaunted Spot, a Picasso Is Persuaded to Curl
headline.print_headline: After 55 Years in Vaunted Spot, a Picasso Is Persuaded to Curl
